summary.long: 1 Samuel is a book of the Old Testament.

verses.text: There was a man named Elkanah who lived in Ramah in the region of Zuph in the hill country of Ephraim. He was the son of Jeroham, son of Elihu, son of Tohu, son of Zuph, of Ephraim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Elkanah had two wives, Hannah and Peninnah. Peninnah had children, but Hannah did not.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Each year Elkanah would travel to Shiloh to worship and sacrifice to the Lord of Heaven’s Armies at the Tabernacle. The priests of the Lord at that time were the two sons of Eli—Hophni and Phinehas.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the days Elkanah presented his sacrifice, he would give portions of the meat to Peninnah and each of her children.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And though he loved Hannah, he would give her only one choice portion because the Lord had given her no children.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Peninnah would taunt Hannah and make fun of her because the Lord had kept her from having children.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Year after year it was the same—Peninnah would taunt Hannah as they went to the Tabernacle. Each time, Hannah would be reduced to tears and would not even eat.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Why are you crying, Hannah?” Elkanah would ask. “Why aren’t you eating? Why be downhearted just because you have no children? You have me—isn’t that better than having ten sons?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Once after a sacrificial meal at Shiloh, Hannah got up and went to pray. Eli the priest was sitting at his customary place beside the entrance of the Tabernacle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hannah was in deep anguish, crying bitterly as she prayed to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And she made this vow: “O Lord of Heaven’s Armies, if you will look upon my sorrow and answer my prayer and give me a son, then I will give him back to you. He will be yours for his entire lifetime, and as a sign that he has been dedicated to the Lord, his hair will never be cut.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As she was praying to the Lord, Eli watched her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Seeing her lips moving but hearing no sound, he thought she had been drinking.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Must you come here drunk?” he demanded. “Throw away your wine!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Oh no, sir!” she replied. “I haven’t been drinking wine or anything stronger. But I am very discouraged, and I was pouring out my heart to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Don’t think I am a wicked woman! For I have been praying out of great anguish and sorrow.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “In that case,” Eli said, “go in peace! May the God of Israel grant the request you have asked of him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Oh, thank you, sir!” she exclaimed. Then she went back and began to eat again, and she was no longer sad.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The entire family got up early the next morning and went to worship the Lord once more. Then they returned home to Ramah. When Elkanah slept with Hannah, the Lord remembered her plea,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and in due time she gave birth to a son. She named him Samuel, for she said, “I asked the Lord for him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The next year Elkanah and his family went on their annual trip to offer a sacrifice to the Lord and to keep his vow.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Hannah did not go. She told her husband, “Wait until the boy is weaned. Then I will take him to the Tabernacle and leave him there with the Lord permanently.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Whatever you think is best,” Elkanah agreed. “Stay here for now, and may the Lord help you keep your promise.” So she stayed home and nursed the boy until he was weaned.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the child was weaned, Hannah took him to the Tabernacle in Shiloh. They brought along a three-year-old bull for the sacrifice and a basket of flour and some wine.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After sacrificing the bull, they brought the boy to Eli.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Sir, do you remember me?” Hannah asked. “I am the very woman who stood here several years ago praying to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I asked the Lord to give me this boy, and he has granted my request.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now I am giving him to the Lord, and he will belong to the Lord his whole life.” And they worshiped the Lord there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then Hannah prayed:
“My heart rejoices in the Lord!
    The Lord has made me strong.
Now I have an answer for my enemies;
    I rejoice because you rescued me.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
“Stop acting so proud and haughty!
    Don’t speak with such arrogance!
For the Lord is a God who knows what you have done;
    he will judge your actions.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The bow of the mighty is now broken,
    and those who stumbled are now strong.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Those who were well fed are now starving,
    and those who were starving are now full.
The childless woman now has seven children,
    and the woman with many children wastes away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Lord gives both death and life;
    he brings some down to the grave but raises others up.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Lord makes some poor and others rich;
    he brings some down and lifts others up.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He lifts the poor from the dust
    and the needy from the garbage dump.
He sets them among princes,
    placing them in seats of honor.
For all the earth is the Lord’s,
    and he has set the world in order.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“He will protect his faithful ones,
    but the wicked will disappear in darkness.
No one will succeed by strength alone.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text: Then Elkanah returned home to Ramah without Samuel. And the boy served the Lord by assisting Eli the priest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the sons of Eli were scoundrels who had no respect for the Lord
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: or for their duties as priests. Whenever anyone offered a sacrifice, Eli’s sons would send over a servant with a three-pronged fork. While the meat of the sacrificed animal was still boiling,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the servant would stick the fork into the pot and demand that whatever it brought up be given to Eli’s sons. All the Israelites who came to worship at Shiloh were treated this way.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Sometimes the servant would come even before the animal’s fat had been burned on the altar. He would demand raw meat before it had been boiled so that it could be used for roasting.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The man offering the sacrifice might reply, “Take as much as you want, but the fat must be burned first.” Then the servant would demand, “No, give it to me now, or I’ll take it by force.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the sin of these young men was very serious in the Lord’s sight, for they treated the Lord’s offerings with contempt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Samuel, though he was only a boy, served the Lord. He wore a linen garment like that of a priest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Each year his mother made a small coat for him and brought it to him when she came with her husband for the sacrifice.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Before they returned home, Eli would bless Elkanah and his wife and say, “May the Lord give you other children to take the place of this one she gave to the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the Lord blessed Hannah, and she conceived and gave birth to three sons and two daughters. Meanwhile, Samuel grew up in the presence of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Eli was very old, but he was aware of what his sons were doing to the people of Israel. He knew, for instance, that his sons were seducing the young women who assisted at the entrance of the Tabernacle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Eli said to them, “I have been hearing reports from all the people about the wicked things you are doing. Why do you keep sinning?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You must stop, my sons! The reports I hear among the Lord’s people are not good.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If someone sins against another person, God can mediate for the guilty party. But if someone sins against the Lord, who can intercede?” But Eli’s sons wouldn’t listen to their father, for the Lord was already planning to put them to death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Meanwhile, the boy Samuel grew taller and grew in favor with the Lord and with the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One day a man of God came to Eli and gave him this message from the Lord: “I revealed myself to your ancestors when they were Pharaoh’s slaves in Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I chose your ancestor Aaron from among all the tribes of Israel to be my priest, to offer sacrifices on my altar, to burn incense, and to wear the priestly vest as he served me. And I assigned the sacrificial offerings to you priests.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So why do you scorn my sacrifices and offerings? Why do you give your sons more honor than you give me—for you and they have become fat from the best offerings of my people Israel!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Therefore, the Lord, the God of Israel, says: I promised that your branch of the tribe of Levi would always be my priests. But I will honor those who honor me, and I will despise those who think lightly of me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The time is coming when I will put an end to your family, so it will no longer serve as my priests. All the members of your family will die before their time. None will reach old age.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You will watch with envy as I pour out prosperity on the people of Israel. But no members of your family will ever live out their days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The few not cut off from serving at my altar will survive, but only so their eyes can go blind and their hearts break, and their children will die a violent death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And to prove that what I have said will come true, I will cause your two sons, Hophni and Phinehas, to die on the same day!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Then I will raise up a faithful priest who will serve me and do what I desire. I will establish his family, and they will be priests to my anointed kings forever.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then all of your surviving family will bow before him, begging for money and food. ‘Please,’ they will say, ‘give us jobs among the priests so we will have enough to eat.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Meanwhile, the boy Samuel served the Lord by assisting Eli. Now in those days messages from the Lord were very rare, and visions were quite uncommon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One night Eli, who was almost blind by now, had gone to bed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The lamp of God had not yet gone out, and Samuel was sleeping in the Tabernacle near the Ark of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Suddenly the Lord called out, “Samuel!”
“Yes?” Samuel replied. “What is it?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He got up and ran to Eli. “Here I am. Did you call me?”
“I didn’t call you,” Eli replied. “Go back to bed.” So he did.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then the Lord called out again, “Samuel!”
Again Samuel got up and went to Eli. “Here I am. Did you call me?”
“I didn’t call you, my son,” Eli said. “Go back to bed.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Samuel did not yet know the Lord because he had never had a message from the Lord before.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So the Lord called a third time, and once more Samuel got up and went to Eli. “Here I am. Did you call me?”
Then Eli realized it was the Lord who was calling the boy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he said to Samuel, “Go and lie down again, and if someone calls again, say, ‘Speak, Lord, your servant is listening.’” So Samuel went back to bed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
And the Lord came and called as before, “Samuel! Samuel!”
And Samuel replied, “Speak, your servant is listening.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Samuel, “I am about to do a shocking thing in Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I am going to carry out all my threats against Eli and his family, from beginning to end.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have warned him that judgment is coming upon his family forever, because his sons are blaspheming God and he hasn’t disciplined them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I have vowed that the sins of Eli and his sons will never be forgiven by sacrifices or offerings.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Samuel stayed in bed until morning, then got up and opened the doors of the Tabernacle as usual. He was afraid to tell Eli what the Lord had said to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But Eli called out to him, “Samuel, my son.”
“Here I am,” Samuel replied.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “What did the Lord say to you? Tell me everything. And may God strike you and even kill you if you hide anything from me!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Samuel told Eli everything; he didn’t hold anything back. “It is the Lord’s will,” Eli replied. “Let him do what he thinks best.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As Samuel grew up, the Lord was with him, and everything Samuel said proved to be reliable.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And all Israel, from Dan in the north to Beersheba in the south, knew that Samuel was confirmed as a prophet of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord continued to appear at Shiloh and gave messages to Samuel there at the Tabernacle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
And Samuel’s words went out to all the people of Israel.
At that time Israel was at war with the Philistines. The Israelite army was camped near Ebenezer, and the Philistines were at Aphek.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Philistines attacked and defeated the army of Israel, killing 4,000 men.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After the battle was over, the troops retreated to their camp, and the elders of Israel asked, “Why did the Lord allow us to be defeated by the Philistines?” Then they said, “Let’s bring the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord from Shiloh. If we carry it into battle with us, it will save us from our enemies.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they sent men to Shiloh to bring the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord of Heaven’s Armies, who is enthroned between the cherubim. Hophni and Phinehas, the sons of Eli, were also there with the Ark of the Covenant of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When all the Israelites saw the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord coming into the camp, their shout of joy was so loud it made the ground shake!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “What’s going on?” the Philistines asked. “What’s all the shouting about in the Hebrew camp?” When they were told it was because the Ark of the Lord had arrived,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: they panicked. “The gods have come into their camp!” they cried. “This is a disaster! We have never had to face anything like this before!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Help! Who can save us from these mighty gods of Israel? They are the same gods who destroyed the Egyptians with plagues when Israel was in the wilderness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Fight as never before, Philistines! If you don’t, we will become the Hebrews’ slaves just as they have been ours! Stand up like men and fight!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Philistines fought desperately, and Israel was defeated again. The slaughter was great; 30,000 Israelite soldiers died that day. The survivors turned and fled to their tents.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Ark of God was captured, and Hophni and Phinehas, the two sons of Eli, were killed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A man from the tribe of Benjamin ran from the battlefield and arrived at Shiloh later that same day. He had torn his clothes and put dust on his head to show his grief.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Eli was waiting beside the road to hear the news of the battle, for his heart trembled for the safety of the Ark of God. When the messenger arrived and told what had happened, an outcry resounded throughout the town.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“What is all the noise about?” Eli asked.
The messenger rushed over to Eli,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: who was ninety-eight years old and blind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He said to Eli, “I have just come from the battlefield—I was there this very day.”
“What happened, my son?” Eli demanded.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Israel has been defeated by the Philistines,” the messenger replied. “The people have been slaughtered, and your two sons, Hophni and Phinehas, were also killed. And the Ark of God has been captured.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the messenger mentioned what had happened to the Ark of God, Eli fell backward from his seat beside the gate. He broke his neck and died, for he was old and overweight. He had been Israel’s judge for forty years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Eli’s daughter-in-law, the wife of Phinehas, was pregnant and near her time of delivery. When she heard that the Ark of God had been captured and that her father-in-law and husband were dead, she went into labor and gave birth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She died in childbirth, but before she passed away the midwives tried to encourage her. “Don’t be afraid,” they said. “You have a baby boy!” But she did not answer or pay attention to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She named the child Ichabod (which means “Where is the glory?”), for she said, “Israel’s glory is gone.” She named him this because the Ark of God had been captured and because her father-in-law and husband were dead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then she said, “The glory has departed from Israel, for the Ark of God has been captured.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After the Philistines captured the Ark of God, they took it from the battleground at Ebenezer to the town of Ashdod.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They carried the Ark of God into the temple of Dagon and placed it beside an idol of Dagon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when the citizens of Ashdod went to see it the next morning, Dagon had fallen with his face to the ground in front of the Ark of the Lord! So they took Dagon and put him in his place again.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the next morning the same thing happened—Dagon had fallen face down before the Ark of the Lord again. This time his head and hands had broken off and were lying in the doorway. Only the trunk of his body was left intact.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That is why to this day neither the priests of Dagon nor anyone who enters the temple of Dagon in Ashdod will step on its threshold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord’s heavy hand struck the people of Ashdod and the nearby villages with a plague of tumors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the people realized what was happening, they cried out, “We can’t keep the Ark of the God of Israel here any longer! He is against us! We will all be destroyed along with Dagon, our god.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So they called together the rulers of the Philistine towns and asked, “What should we do with the Ark of the God of Israel?”
The rulers discussed it and replied, “Move it to the town of Gath.” So they moved the Ark of the God of Israel to Gath.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when the Ark arrived at Gath, the Lord’s heavy hand fell on its men, young and old; he struck them with a plague of tumors, and there was a great panic.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they sent the Ark of God to the town of Ekron, but when the people of Ekron saw it coming they cried out, “They are bringing the Ark of the God of Israel here to kill us, too!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people summoned the Philistine rulers again and begged them, “Please send the Ark of the God of Israel back to its own country, or it will kill us all.” For the deadly plague from God had already begun, and great fear was sweeping across the town.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Those who didn’t die were afflicted with tumors; and the cry from the town rose to heaven.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Ark of the Lord remained in Philistine territory seven months in all.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Philistines called in their priests and diviners and asked them, “What should we do about the Ark of the Lord? Tell us how to return it to its own country.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Send the Ark of the God of Israel back with a gift,” they were told. “Send a guilt offering so the plague will stop. Then, if you are healed, you will know it was his hand that caused the plague.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“What sort of guilt offering should we send?” they asked.
And they were told, “Since the plague has struck both you and your five rulers, make five gold tumors and five gold rats, just like those that have ravaged your land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Make these things to show honor to the God of Israel. Perhaps then he will stop afflicting you, your gods, and your land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Don’t be stubborn and rebellious as Pharaoh and the Egyptians were. By the time God was finished with them, they were eager to let Israel go.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Now build a new cart, and find two cows that have just given birth to calves. Make sure the cows have never been yoked to a cart. Hitch the cows to the cart, but shut their calves away from them in a pen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Put the Ark of the Lord on the cart, and beside it place a chest containing the gold rats and gold tumors you are sending as a guilt offering. Then let the cows go wherever they want.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If they cross the border of our land and go to Beth-shemesh, we will know it was the Lord who brought this great disaster upon us. If they don’t, we will know it was not his hand that caused the plague. It came simply by chance.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So these instructions were carried out. Two cows were hitched to the cart, and their newborn calves were shut up in a pen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Ark of the Lord and the chest containing the gold rats and gold tumors were placed on the cart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And sure enough, without veering off in other directions, the cows went straight along the road toward Beth-shemesh, lowing as they went. The Philistine rulers followed them as far as the border of Beth-shemesh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people of Beth-shemesh were harvesting wheat in the valley, and when they saw the Ark, they were overjoyed!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The cart came into the field of a man named Joshua and stopped beside a large rock. So the people broke up the wood of the cart for a fire and killed the cows and sacrificed them to the Lord as a burnt offering.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Several men of the tribe of Levi lifted the Ark of the Lord and the chest containing the gold rats and gold tumors from the cart and placed them on the large rock. Many sacrifices and burnt offerings were offered to the Lord that day by the people of Beth-shemesh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The five Philistine rulers watched all this and then returned to Ekron that same day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The five gold tumors sent by the Philistines as a guilt offering to the Lord were gifts from the rulers of Ashdod, Gaza, Ashkelon, Gath, and Ekron.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The five gold rats represented the five Philistine towns and their surrounding villages, which were controlled by the five rulers. The large rock at Beth-shemesh, where they set the Ark of the Lord, still stands in the field of Joshua as a witness to what happened there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the Lord killed seventy men from Beth-shemesh because they looked into the Ark of the Lord. And the people mourned greatly because of what the Lord had done.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Who is able to stand in the presence of the Lord, this holy God?” they cried out. “Where can we send the Ark from here?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they sent messengers to the people at Kiriath-jearim and told them, “The Philistines have returned the Ark of the Lord. Come here and get it!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the men of Kiriath-jearim came to get the Ark of the Lord. They took it to the hillside home of Abinadab and ordained Eleazar, his son, to be in charge of it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Ark remained in Kiriath-jearim for a long time—twenty years in all. During that time all Israel mourned because it seemed the Lord had abandoned them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Samuel said to all the people of Israel, “If you want to return to the Lord with all your hearts, get rid of your foreign gods and your images of Ashtoreth. Turn your hearts to the Lord and obey him alone; then he will rescue you from the Philistines.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Israelites got rid of their images of Baal and Ashtoreth and worshiped only the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Samuel told them, “Gather all of Israel to Mizpah, and I will pray to the Lord for you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they gathered at Mizpah and, in a great ceremony, drew water from a well and poured it out before the Lord. They also went without food all day and confessed that they had sinned against the Lord. (It was at Mizpah that Samuel became Israel’s judge.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Philistine rulers heard that Israel had gathered at Mizpah, they mobilized their army and advanced. The Israelites were badly frightened when they learned that the Philistines were approaching.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Don’t stop pleading with the Lord our God to save us from the Philistines!” they begged Samuel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Samuel took a young lamb and offered it to the Lord as a whole burnt offering. He pleaded with the Lord to help Israel, and the Lord answered him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Just as Samuel was sacrificing the burnt offering, the Philistines arrived to attack Israel. But the Lord spoke with a mighty voice of thunder from heaven that day, and the Philistines were thrown into such confusion that the Israelites defeated them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The men of Israel chased them from Mizpah to a place below Beth-car, slaughtering them all along the way.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Samuel then took a large stone and placed it between the towns of Mizpah and Jeshanah. He named it Ebenezer (which means “the stone of help”), for he said, “Up to this point the Lord has helped us!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Philistines were subdued and didn’t invade Israel again for some time. And throughout Samuel’s lifetime, the Lord’s powerful hand was raised against the Philistines.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Israelite villages near Ekron and Gath that the Philistines had captured were restored to Israel, along with the rest of the territory that the Philistines had taken. And there was peace between Israel and the Amorites in those days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Samuel continued as Israel’s judge for the rest of his life.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Each year he traveled around, setting up his court first at Bethel, then at Gilgal, and then at Mizpah. He judged the people of Israel at each of these places.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he would return to his home at Ramah, and he would hear cases there, too. And Samuel built an altar to the Lord at Ramah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As Samuel grew old, he appointed his sons to be judges over Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joel and Abijah, his oldest sons, held court in Beersheba.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But they were not like their father, for they were greedy for money. They accepted bribes and perverted justice.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Finally, all the elders of Israel met at Ramah to discuss the matter with Samuel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Look,” they told him, “you are now old, and your sons are not like you. Give us a king to judge us like all the other nations have.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Samuel was displeased with their request and went to the Lord for guidance.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Do everything they say to you,” the Lord replied, “for they are rejecting me, not you. They don’t want me to be their king any longer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ever since I brought them from Egypt they have continually abandoned me and followed other gods. And now they are giving you the same treatment.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Do as they ask, but solemnly warn them about the way a king will reign over them.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Samuel passed on the Lord’s warning to the people who were asking him for a king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is how a king will reign over you,” Samuel said. “The king will draft your sons and assign them to his chariots and his charioteers, making them run before his chariots.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some will be generals and captains in his army, some will be forced to plow in his fields and harvest his crops, and some will make his weapons and chariot equipment.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king will take your daughters from you and force them to cook and bake and make perfumes for him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He will take away the best of your fields and vineyards and olive groves and give them to his own officials.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He will take a tenth of your grain and your grape harvest and distribute it among his officers and attendants.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He will take your male and female slaves and demand the finest of your cattle and donkeys for his own use.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He will demand a tenth of your flocks, and you will be his slaves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When that day comes, you will beg for relief from this king you are demanding, but then the Lord will not help you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the people refused to listen to Samuel’s warning. “Even so, we still want a king,” they said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “We want to be like the nations around us. Our king will judge us and lead us into battle.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Samuel repeated to the Lord what the people had said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and the Lord replied, “Do as they say, and give them a king.” Then Samuel agreed and sent the people home.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was a wealthy, influential man named Kish from the tribe of Benjamin. He was the son of Abiel, son of Zeror, son of Becorath, son of Aphiah, of the tribe of Benjamin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His son Saul was the most handsome man in Israel—head and shoulders taller than anyone else in the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One day Kish’s donkeys strayed away, and he told Saul, “Take a servant with you, and go look for the donkeys.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Saul took one of the servants and traveled through the hill country of Ephraim, the land of Shalishah, the Shaalim area, and the entire land of Benjamin, but they couldn’t find the donkeys anywhere.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Finally, they entered the region of Zuph, and Saul said to his servant, “Let’s go home. By now my father will be more worried about us than about the donkeys!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the servant said, “I’ve just thought of something! There is a man of God who lives here in this town. He is held in high honor by all the people because everything he says comes true. Let’s go find him. Perhaps he can tell us which way to go.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “But we don’t have anything to offer him,” Saul replied. “Even our food is gone, and we don’t have a thing to give him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Well,” the servant said, “I have one small silver piece. We can at least offer it to the man of God and see what happens!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (In those days if people wanted a message from God, they would say, “Let’s go and ask the seer,” for prophets used to be called seers.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “All right,” Saul agreed, “let’s try it!” So they started into the town where the man of God lived.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As they were climbing the hill to the town, they met some young women coming out to draw water. So Saul and his servant asked, “Is the seer here today?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Yes,” they replied. “Stay right on this road. He is at the town gates. He has just arrived to take part in a public sacrifice up at the place of worship.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hurry and catch him before he goes up there to eat. The guests won’t begin eating until he arrives to bless the food.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they entered the town, and as they passed through the gates, Samuel was coming out toward them to go up to the place of worship.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the Lord had told Samuel the previous day,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “About this time tomorrow I will send you a man from the land of Benjamin. Anoint him to be the leader of my people, Israel. He will rescue them from the Philistines, for I have looked down on my people in mercy and have heard their cry.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Samuel saw Saul, the Lord said, “That’s the man I told you about! He will rule my people.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Just then Saul approached Samuel at the gateway and asked, “Can you please tell me where the seer’s house is?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I am the seer!” Samuel replied. “Go up to the place of worship ahead of me. We will eat there together, and in the morning I’ll tell you what you want to know and send you on your way.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And don’t worry about those donkeys that were lost three days ago, for they have been found. And I am here to tell you that you and your family are the focus of all Israel’s hopes.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul replied, “But I’m only from the tribe of Benjamin, the smallest tribe in Israel, and my family is the least important of all the families of that tribe! Why are you talking like this to me?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Samuel brought Saul and his servant into the hall and placed them at the head of the table, honoring them above the thirty special guests.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Samuel then instructed the cook to bring Saul the finest cut of meat, the piece that had been set aside for the guest of honor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the cook brought in the meat and placed it before Saul. “Go ahead and eat it,” Samuel said. “I was saving it for you even before I invited these others!” So Saul ate with Samuel that day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they came down from the place of worship and returned to town, Samuel took Saul up to the roof of the house and prepared a bed for him there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At daybreak the next morning, Samuel called to Saul, “Get up! It’s time you were on your way.” So Saul got ready, and he and Samuel left the house together.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they reached the edge of town, Samuel told Saul to send his servant on ahead. After the servant was gone, Samuel said, “Stay here, for I have received a special message for you from God.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Samuel took a flask of olive oil and poured it over Saul’s head. He kissed Saul and said, “I am doing this because the Lord has appointed you to be the ruler over Israel, his special possession.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When you leave me today, you will see two men beside Rachel’s tomb at Zelzah, on the border of Benjamin. They will tell you that the donkeys have been found and that your father has stopped worrying about them and is now worried about you. He is asking, ‘Have you seen my son?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “When you get to the oak of Tabor, you will see three men coming toward you who are on their way to worship God at Bethel. One will be bringing three young goats, another will have three loaves of bread, and the third will be carrying a wineskin full of wine.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They will greet you and offer you two of the loaves, which you are to accept.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “When you arrive at Gibeah of God, where the garrison of the Philistines is located, you will meet a band of prophets coming down from the place of worship. They will be playing a harp, a tambourine, a flute, and a lyre, and they will be prophesying.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At that time the Spirit of the Lord will come powerfully upon you, and you will prophesy with them. You will be changed into a different person.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After these signs take place, do what must be done, for God is with you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then go down to Gilgal ahead of me. I will join you there to sacrifice burnt offerings and peace offerings. You must wait for seven days until I arrive and give you further instructions.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As Saul turned and started to leave, God gave him a new heart, and all Samuel’s signs were fulfilled that day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Saul and his servant arrived at Gibeah, they saw a group of prophets coming toward them. Then the Spirit of God came powerfully upon Saul, and he, too, began to prophesy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When those who knew Saul heard about it, they exclaimed, “What? Is even Saul a prophet? How did the son of Kish become a prophet?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And one of those standing there said, “Can anyone become a prophet, no matter who his father is?” So that is the origin of the saying “Is even Saul a prophet?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Saul had finished prophesying, he went up to the place of worship.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Where have you been?” Saul’s uncle asked him and his servant.
“We were looking for the donkeys,” Saul replied, “but we couldn’t find them. So we went to Samuel to ask him where they were.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Oh? And what did he say?” his uncle asked.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “He told us that the donkeys had already been found,” Saul replied. But Saul didn’t tell his uncle what Samuel said about the kingdom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Later Samuel called all the people of Israel to meet before the Lord at Mizpah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And he said, “This is what the Lord, the God of Israel, has declared: I brought you from Egypt and rescued you from the Egyptians and from all of the nations that were oppressing you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But though I have rescued you from your misery and distress, you have rejected your God today and have said, ‘No, we want a king instead!’ Now, therefore, present yourselves before the Lord by tribes and clans.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Samuel brought all the tribes of Israel before the Lord, and the tribe of Benjamin was chosen by lot.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he brought each family of the tribe of Benjamin before the Lord, and the family of the Matrites was chosen. And finally Saul son of Kish was chosen from among them. But when they looked for him, he had disappeared!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So they asked the Lord, “Where is he?”
And the Lord replied, “He is hiding among the baggage.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they found him and brought him out, and he stood head and shoulders above anyone else.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then Samuel said to all the people, “This is the man the Lord has chosen as your king. No one in all Israel is like him!”
And all the people shouted, “Long live the king!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Samuel told the people what the rights and duties of a king were. He wrote them down on a scroll and placed it before the Lord. Then Samuel sent the people home again.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Saul returned to his home at Gibeah, a group of men whose hearts God had touched went with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But there were some scoundrels who complained, “How can this man save us?” And they scorned him and refused to bring him gifts. But Saul ignored them.
[Nahash, king of the Ammonites, had been grievously oppressing the people of Gad and Reuben who lived east of the Jordan River. He gouged out the right eye of each of the Israelites living there, and he didn’t allow anyone to come and rescue them. In fact, of all the Israelites east of the Jordan, there wasn’t a single one whose right eye Nahash had not gouged out. But there were 7,000 men who had escaped from the Ammonites, and they had settled in Jabesh-gilead.]
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: About a month later, King Nahash of Ammon led his army against the Israelite town of Jabesh-gilead. But all the citizens of Jabesh asked for peace. “Make a treaty with us, and we will be your servants,” they pleaded.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “All right,” Nahash said, “but only on one condition. I will gouge out the right eye of every one of you as a disgrace to all Israel!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Give us seven days to send messengers throughout Israel!” replied the elders of Jabesh. “If no one comes to save us, we will agree to your terms.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the messengers came to Gibeah of Saul and told the people about their plight, everyone broke into tears.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul had been plowing a field with his oxen, and when he returned to town, he asked, “What’s the matter? Why is everyone crying?” So they told him about the message from Jabesh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Spirit of God came powerfully upon Saul, and he became very angry.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He took two oxen and cut them into pieces and sent the messengers to carry them throughout Israel with this message: “This is what will happen to the oxen of anyone who refuses to follow Saul and Samuel into battle!” And the Lord made the people afraid of Saul’s anger, and all of them came out together as one.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Saul mobilized them at Bezek, he found that there were 300,000 men from Israel and 30,000 men from Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Saul sent the messengers back to Jabesh-gilead to say, “We will rescue you by noontime tomorrow!” There was great joy throughout the town when that message arrived!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The men of Jabesh then told their enemies, “Tomorrow we will come out to you, and you can do to us whatever you wish.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But before dawn the next morning, Saul arrived, having divided his army into three detachments. He launched a surprise attack against the Ammonites and slaughtered them the whole morning. The remnant of their army was so badly scattered that no two of them were left together.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the people exclaimed to Samuel, “Now where are those men who said, ‘Why should Saul rule over us?’ Bring them here, and we will kill them!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Saul replied, “No one will be executed today, for today the Lord has rescued Israel!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Samuel said to the people, “Come, let us all go to Gilgal to renew the kingdom.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they all went to Gilgal, and in a solemn ceremony before the Lord they made Saul king. Then they offered peace offerings to the Lord, and Saul and all the Israelites were filled with joy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Samuel addressed all Israel: “I have done as you asked and given you a king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Your king is now your leader. I stand here before you—an old, gray-haired man—and my sons serve you. I have served as your leader from the time I was a boy to this very day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now testify against me in the presence of the Lord and before his anointed one. Whose ox or donkey have I stolen? Have I ever cheated any of you? Have I ever oppressed you? Have I ever taken a bribe and perverted justice? Tell me and I will make right whatever I have done wrong.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “No,” they replied, “you have never cheated or oppressed us, and you have never taken even a single bribe.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“The Lord and his anointed one are my witnesses today,” Samuel declared, “that my hands are clean.”
“Yes, he is a witness,” they replied.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “It was the Lord who appointed Moses and Aaron,” Samuel continued. “He brought your ancestors out of the land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now stand here quietly before the Lord as I remind you of all the great things the Lord has done for you and your ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “When the Israelites were in Egypt and cried out to the Lord, he sent Moses and Aaron to rescue them from Egypt and to bring them into this land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the people soon forgot about the Lord their God, so he handed them over to Sisera, the commander of Hazor’s army, and also to the Philistines and to the king of Moab, who fought against them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Then they cried to the Lord again and confessed, ‘We have sinned by turning away from the Lord and worshiping the images of Baal and Ashtoreth. But we will worship you and you alone if you will rescue us from our enemies.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord sent Gideon, Bedan, Jephthah, and Samuel to save you, and you lived in safety.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “But when you were afraid of Nahash, the king of Ammon, you came to me and said that you wanted a king to reign over you, even though the Lord your God was already your king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All right, here is the king you have chosen. You asked for him, and the Lord has granted your request.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Now if you fear and worship the Lord and listen to his voice, and if you do not rebel against the Lord’s commands, then both you and your king will show that you recognize the Lord as your God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if you rebel against the Lord’s commands and refuse to listen to him, then his hand will be as heavy upon you as it was upon your ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Now stand here and see the great thing the Lord is about to do.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You know that it does not rain at this time of the year during the wheat harvest. I will ask the Lord to send thunder and rain today. Then you will realize how wicked you have been in asking the Lord for a king!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Samuel called to the Lord, and the Lord sent thunder and rain that day. And all the people were terrified of the Lord and of Samuel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Pray to the Lord your God for us, or we will die!” they all said to Samuel. “For now we have added to our sins by asking for a king.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Don’t be afraid,” Samuel reassured them. “You have certainly done wrong, but make sure now that you worship the Lord with all your heart, and don’t turn your back on him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Don’t go back to worshiping worthless idols that cannot help or rescue you—they are totally useless!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord will not abandon his people, because that would dishonor his great name. For it has pleased the Lord to make you his very own people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “As for me, I will certainly not sin against the Lord by ending my prayers for you. And I will continue to teach you what is good and right.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But be sure to fear the Lord and faithfully serve him. Think of all the wonderful things he has done for you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if you continue to sin, you and your king will be swept away.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul was thirty years old when he became king, and he reigned for forty-two years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul selected 3,000 special troops from the army of Israel and sent the rest of the men home. He took 2,000 of the chosen men with him to Micmash and the hill country of Bethel. The other 1,000 went with Saul’s son Jonathan to Gibeah in the land of Benjamin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Soon after this, Jonathan attacked and defeated the garrison of Philistines at Geba. The news spread quickly among the Philistines. So Saul blew the ram’s horn throughout the land, saying, “Hebrews, hear this! Rise up in revolt!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All Israel heard the news that Saul had destroyed the Philistine garrison at Geba and that the Philistines now hated the Israelites more than ever. So the entire Israelite army was summoned to join Saul at Gilgal.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Philistines mustered a mighty army of 3,000 chariots, 6,000 charioteers, and as many warriors as the grains of sand on the seashore! They camped at Micmash east of Beth-aven.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The men of Israel saw what a tight spot they were in; and because they were hard pressed by the enemy, they tried to hide in caves, thickets, rocks, holes, and cisterns.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Some of them crossed the Jordan River and escaped into the land of Gad and Gilead.
Meanwhile, Saul stayed at Gilgal, and his men were trembling with fear.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul waited there seven days for Samuel, as Samuel had instructed him earlier, but Samuel still didn’t come. Saul realized that his troops were rapidly slipping away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he demanded, “Bring me the burnt offering and the peace offerings!” And Saul sacrificed the burnt offering himself.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Just as Saul was finishing with the burnt offering, Samuel arrived. Saul went out to meet and welcome him,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
but Samuel said, “What is this you have done?”
Saul replied, “I saw my men scattering from me, and you didn’t arrive when you said you would, and the Philistines are at Micmash ready for battle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I said, ‘The Philistines are ready to march against us at Gilgal, and I haven’t even asked for the Lord’s help!’ So I felt compelled to offer the burnt offering myself before you came.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “How foolish!” Samuel exclaimed. “You have not kept the command the Lord your God gave you. Had you kept it, the Lord would have established your kingdom over Israel forever.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But now your kingdom must end, for the Lord has sought out a man after his own heart. The Lord has already appointed him to be the leader of his people, because you have not kept the Lord’s command.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Samuel then left Gilgal and went on his way, but the rest of the troops went with Saul to meet the army. They went up from Gilgal to Gibeah in the land of Benjamin. When Saul counted the men who were still with him, he found only 600 were left!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul and Jonathan and the troops with them were staying at Geba in the land of Benjamin. The Philistines set up their camp at Micmash.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Three raiding parties soon left the camp of the Philistines. One went north toward Ophrah in the land of Shual,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: another went west to Beth-horon, and the third moved toward the border above the valley of Zeboim near the wilderness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There were no blacksmiths in the land of Israel in those days. The Philistines wouldn’t allow them for fear they would make swords and spears for the Hebrews.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So whenever the Israelites needed to sharpen their plowshares, picks, axes, or sickles, they had to take them to a Philistine blacksmith.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The charges were as follows: a quarter of an ounce of silver for sharpening a plowshare or a pick, and an eighth of an ounce for sharpening an ax or making the point of an ox goad.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So on the day of the battle none of the people of Israel had a sword or spear, except for Saul and Jonathan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The pass at Micmash had meanwhile been secured by a contingent of the Philistine army.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One day Jonathan said to his armor bearer, “Come on, let’s go over to where the Philistines have their outpost.” But Jonathan did not tell his father what he was doing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Meanwhile, Saul and his 600 men were camped on the outskirts of Gibeah, around the pomegranate tree at Migron.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Among Saul’s men was Ahijah the priest, who was wearing the ephod, the priestly vest. Ahijah was the son of Ichabod’s brother Ahitub, son of Phinehas, son of Eli, the priest of the Lord who had served at Shiloh.
No one realized that Jonathan had left the Israelite camp.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: To reach the Philistine outpost, Jonathan had to go down between two rocky cliffs that were called Bozez and Seneh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The cliff on the north was in front of Micmash, and the one on the south was in front of Geba.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Let’s go across to the outpost of those pagans,” Jonathan said to his armor bearer. “Perhaps the Lord will help us, for nothing can hinder the Lord. He can win a battle whether he has many warriors or only a few!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Do what you think is best,” the armor bearer replied. “I’m with you completely, whatever you decide.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “All right, then,” Jonathan told him. “We will cross over and let them see us.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If they say to us, ‘Stay where you are or we’ll kill you,’ then we will stop and not go up to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if they say, ‘Come on up and fight,’ then we will go up. That will be the Lord’s sign that he will help us defeat them.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Philistines saw them coming, they shouted, “Look! The Hebrews are crawling out of their holes!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then the men from the outpost shouted to Jonathan, “Come on up here, and we’ll teach you a lesson!”
“Come on, climb right behind me,” Jonathan said to his armor bearer, “for the Lord will help us defeat them!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they climbed up using both hands and feet, and the Philistines fell before Jonathan, and his armor bearer killed those who came behind them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They killed some twenty men in all, and their bodies were scattered over about half an acre.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Suddenly, panic broke out in the Philistine army, both in the camp and in the field, including even the outposts and raiding parties. And just then an earthquake struck, and everyone was terrified.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul’s lookouts in Gibeah of Benjamin saw a strange sight—the vast army of Philistines began to melt away in every direction.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Call the roll and find out who’s missing,” Saul ordered. And when they checked, they found that Jonathan and his armor bearer were gone.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Saul shouted to Ahijah, “Bring the ephod here!” For at that time Ahijah was wearing the ephod in front of the Israelites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But while Saul was talking to the priest, the confusion in the Philistine camp grew louder and louder. So Saul said to the priest, “Never mind; let’s get going!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Saul and all his men rushed out to the battle and found the Philistines killing each other. There was terrible confusion everywhere.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Even the Hebrews who had previously gone over to the Philistine army revolted and joined in with Saul, Jonathan, and the rest of the Israelites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Likewise, the men of Israel who were hiding in the hill country of Ephraim joined the chase when they saw the Philistines running away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Lord saved Israel that day, and the battle continued to rage even beyond Beth-aven.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the men of Israel were pressed to exhaustion that day, because Saul had placed them under an oath, saying, “Let a curse fall on anyone who eats before evening—before I have full revenge on my enemies.” So no one ate anything all day,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: even though they had all found honeycomb on the ground in the forest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They didn’t dare touch the honey because they all feared the oath they had taken.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Jonathan had not heard his father’s command, and he dipped the end of his stick into a piece of honeycomb and ate the honey. After he had eaten it, he felt refreshed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But one of the men saw him and said, “Your father made the army take a strict oath that anyone who eats food today will be cursed. That is why everyone is weary and faint.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “My father has made trouble for us all!” Jonathan exclaimed. “A command like that only hurts us. See how refreshed I am now that I have eaten this little bit of honey.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If the men had been allowed to eat freely from the food they found among our enemies, think how many more Philistines we could have killed!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They chased and killed the Philistines all day from Micmash to Aijalon, growing more and more faint.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That evening they rushed for the battle plunder and butchered the sheep, goats, cattle, and calves, but they ate them without draining the blood.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Someone reported to Saul, “Look, the men are sinning against the Lord by eating meat that still has blood in it.”
“That is very wrong,” Saul said. “Find a large stone and roll it over here.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then go out among the troops and tell them, ‘Bring the cattle, sheep, and goats here to me. Kill them here, and drain the blood before you eat them. Do not sin against the Lord by eating meat with the blood still in it.’”
So that night all the troops brought their animals and slaughtered them there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Saul built an altar to the Lord; it was the first of the altars he built to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then Saul said, “Let’s chase the Philistines all night and plunder them until sunrise. Let’s destroy every last one of them.”
His men replied, “We’ll do whatever you think is best.”
But the priest said, “Let’s ask God first.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Saul asked God, “Should we go after the Philistines? Will you help us defeat them?” But God made no reply that day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Saul said to the leaders, “Something’s wrong! I want all my army commanders to come here. We must find out what sin was committed today.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I vow by the name of the Lord who rescued Israel that the sinner will surely die, even if it is my own son Jonathan!” But no one would tell him what the trouble was.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then Saul said, “Jonathan and I will stand over here, and all of you stand over there.”
And the people responded to Saul, “Whatever you think is best.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Saul prayed, “O Lord, God of Israel, please show us who is guilty and who is innocent.” Then they cast sacred lots, and Jonathan and Saul were chosen as the guilty ones, and the people were declared innocent.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Saul said, “Now cast lots again and choose between me and Jonathan.” And Jonathan was shown to be the guilty one.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Tell me what you have done,” Saul demanded of Jonathan.
“I tasted a little honey,” Jonathan admitted. “It was only a little bit on the end of my stick. Does that deserve death?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Yes, Jonathan,” Saul said, “you must die! May God strike me and even kill me if you do not die for this.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the people broke in and said to Saul, “Jonathan has won this great victory for Israel. Should he die? Far from it! As surely as the Lord lives, not one hair on his head will be touched, for God helped him do a great deed today.” So the people rescued Jonathan, and he was not put to death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Saul called back the army from chasing the Philistines, and the Philistines returned home.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now when Saul had secured his grasp on Israel’s throne, he fought against his enemies in every direction—against Moab, Ammon, Edom, the kings of Zobah, and the Philistines. And wherever he turned, he was victorious.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He performed great deeds and conquered the Amalekites, saving Israel from all those who had plundered them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul’s sons included Jonathan, Ishbosheth, and Malkishua. He also had two daughters: Merab, who was older, and Michal.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul’s wife was Ahinoam, the daughter of Ahimaaz. The commander of Saul’s army was Abner, the son of Saul’s uncle Ner.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul’s father, Kish, and Abner’s father, Ner, were both sons of Abiel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Israelites fought constantly with the Philistines throughout Saul’s lifetime. So whenever Saul observed a young man who was brave and strong, he drafted him into his army.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One day Samuel said to Saul, “It was the Lord who told me to anoint you as king of his people, Israel. Now listen to this message from the Lord!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what the Lord of Heaven’s Armies has declared: I have decided to settle accounts with the nation of Amalek for opposing Israel when they came from Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now go and completely destroy the entire Amalekite nation—men, women, children, babies, cattle, sheep, goats, camels, and donkeys.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Saul mobilized his army at Telaim. There were 200,000 soldiers from Israel and 10,000 men from Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Saul and his army went to a town of the Amalekites and lay in wait in the valley.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul sent this warning to the Kenites: “Move away from where the Amalekites live, or you will die with them. For you showed kindness to all the people of Israel when they came up from Egypt.” So the Kenites packed up and left.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Saul slaughtered the Amalekites from Havilah all the way to Shur, east of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He captured Agag, the Amalekite king, but completely destroyed everyone else.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul and his men spared Agag’s life and kept the best of the sheep and goats, the cattle, the fat calves, and the lambs—everything, in fact, that appealed to them. They destroyed only what was worthless or of poor quality.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Samuel,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I am sorry that I ever made Saul king, for he has not been loyal to me and has refused to obey my command.” Samuel was so deeply moved when he heard this that he cried out to the Lord all night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Early the next morning Samuel went to find Saul. Someone told him, “Saul went to the town of Carmel to set up a monument to himself; then he went on to Gilgal.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Samuel finally found him, Saul greeted him cheerfully. “May the Lord bless you,” he said. “I have carried out the Lord’s command!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Then what is all the bleating of sheep and goats and the lowing of cattle I hear?” Samuel demanded.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “It’s true that the army spared the best of the sheep, goats, and cattle,” Saul admitted. “But they are going to sacrifice them to the Lord your God. We have destroyed everything else.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then Samuel said to Saul, “Stop! Listen to what the Lord told me last night!”
“What did he tell you?” Saul asked.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Samuel told him, “Although you may think little of yourself, are you not the leader of the tribes of Israel? The Lord has anointed you king of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the Lord sent you on a mission and told you, ‘Go and completely destroy the sinners, the Amalekites, until they are all dead.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Why haven’t you obeyed the Lord? Why did you rush for the plunder and do what was evil in the Lord’s sight?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “But I did obey the Lord,” Saul insisted. “I carried out the mission he gave me. I brought back King Agag, but I destroyed everyone else.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then my troops brought in the best of the sheep, goats, cattle, and plunder to sacrifice to the Lord your God in Gilgal.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But Samuel replied, 
“What is more pleasing to the Lord:
    your burnt offerings and sacrifices
    or your obedience to his voice?
Listen! Obedience is better than sacrifice,
    and submission is better than offering the fat of rams.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Rebellion is as sinful as witchcraft,
    and stubbornness as bad as worshiping idols.
So because you have rejected the command of the Lord,
    he has rejected you as king.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Saul admitted to Samuel, “Yes, I have sinned. I have disobeyed your instructions and the Lord’s command, for I was afraid of the people and did what they demanded.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But now, please forgive my sin and come back with me so that I may worship the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Samuel replied, “I will not go back with you! Since you have rejected the Lord’s command, he has rejected you as king of Israel.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As Samuel turned to go, Saul tried to hold him back and tore the hem of his robe.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Samuel said to him, “The Lord has torn the kingdom of Israel from you today and has given it to someone else—one who is better than you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And he who is the Glory of Israel will not lie, nor will he change his mind, for he is not human that he should change his mind!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Saul pleaded again, “I know I have sinned. But please, at least honor me before the elders of my people and before Israel by coming back with me so that I may worship the Lord your God.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Samuel finally agreed and went back with him, and Saul worshiped the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Samuel said, “Bring King Agag to me.” Agag arrived full of hope, for he thought, “Surely the worst is over, and I have been spared!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Samuel said, “As your sword has killed the sons of many mothers, now your mother will be childless.” And Samuel cut Agag to pieces before the Lord at Gilgal.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Samuel went home to Ramah, and Saul returned to his house at Gibeah of Saul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Samuel never went to meet with Saul again, but he mourned constantly for him. And the Lord was sorry he had ever made Saul king of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the Lord said to Samuel, “You have mourned long enough for Saul. I have rejected him as king of Israel, so fill your flask with olive oil and go to Bethlehem. Find a man named Jesse who lives there, for I have selected one of his sons to be my king.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But Samuel asked, “How can I do that? If Saul hears about it, he will kill me.”
“Take a heifer with you,” the Lord replied, “and say that you have come to make a sacrifice to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Invite Jesse to the sacrifice, and I will show you which of his sons to anoint for me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Samuel did as the Lord instructed. When he arrived at Bethlehem, the elders of the town came trembling to meet him. “What’s wrong?” they asked. “Do you come in peace?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Yes,” Samuel replied. “I have come to sacrifice to the Lord. Purify yourselves and come with me to the sacrifice.” Then Samuel performed the purification rite for Jesse and his sons and invited them to the sacrifice, too.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they arrived, Samuel took one look at Eliab and thought, “Surely this is the Lord’s anointed!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the Lord said to Samuel, “Don’t judge by his appearance or height, for I have rejected him. The Lord doesn’t see things the way you see them. People judge by outward appearance, but the Lord looks at the heart.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jesse told his son Abinadab to step forward and walk in front of Samuel. But Samuel said, “This is not the one the Lord has chosen.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Next Jesse summoned Shimea, but Samuel said, “Neither is this the one the Lord has chosen.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the same way all seven of Jesse’s sons were presented to Samuel. But Samuel said to Jesse, “The Lord has not chosen any of these.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then Samuel asked, “Are these all the sons you have?”
“There is still the youngest,” Jesse replied. “But he’s out in the fields watching the sheep and goats.”
“Send for him at once,” Samuel said. “We will not sit down to eat until he arrives.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So Jesse sent for him. He was dark and handsome, with beautiful eyes.
And the Lord said, “This is the one; anoint him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So as David stood there among his brothers, Samuel took the flask of olive oil he had brought and anointed David with the oil. And the Spirit of the Lord came powerfully upon David from that day on. Then Samuel returned to Ramah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the Spirit of the Lord had left Saul, and the Lord sent a tormenting spirit that filled him with depression and fear.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some of Saul’s servants said to him, “A tormenting spirit from God is troubling you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Let us find a good musician to play the harp whenever the tormenting spirit troubles you. He will play soothing music, and you will soon be well again.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “All right,” Saul said. “Find me someone who plays well, and bring him here.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One of the servants said to Saul, “One of Jesse’s sons from Bethlehem is a talented harp player. Not only that—he is a brave warrior, a man of war, and has good judgment. He is also a fine-looking young man, and the Lord is with him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Saul sent messengers to Jesse to say, “Send me your son David, the shepherd.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jesse responded by sending David to Saul, along with a young goat, a donkey loaded with bread, and a wineskin full of wine.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David went to Saul and began serving him. Saul loved David very much, and David became his armor bearer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Saul sent word to Jesse asking, “Please let David remain in my service, for I am very pleased with him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And whenever the tormenting spirit from God troubled Saul, David would play the harp. Then Saul would feel better, and the tormenting spirit would go away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Philistines now mustered their army for battle and camped between Socoh in Judah and Azekah at Ephes-dammim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul countered by gathering his Israelite troops near the valley of Elah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Philistines and Israelites faced each other on opposite hills, with the valley between them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Goliath, a Philistine champion from Gath, came out of the Philistine ranks to face the forces of Israel. He was over nine feet tall!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He wore a bronze helmet, and his bronze coat of mail weighed 125 pounds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also wore bronze leg armor, and he carried a bronze javelin on his shoulder.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The shaft of his spear was as heavy and thick as a weaver’s beam, tipped with an iron spearhead that weighed 15 pounds. His armor bearer walked ahead of him carrying a shield.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Goliath stood and shouted a taunt across to the Israelites. “Why are you all coming out to fight?” he called. “I am the Philistine champion, but you are only the servants of Saul. Choose one man to come down here and fight me!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If he kills me, then we will be your slaves. But if I kill him, you will be our slaves!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I defy the armies of Israel today! Send me a man who will fight me!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Saul and the Israelites heard this, they were terrified and deeply shaken.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now David was the son of a man named Jesse, an Ephrathite from Bethlehem in the land of Judah. Jesse was an old man at that time, and he had eight sons.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jesse’s three oldest sons—Eliab, Abinadab, and Shimea—had already joined Saul’s army to fight the Philistines.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David was the youngest son. David’s three oldest brothers stayed with Saul’s army,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but David went back and forth so he could help his father with the sheep in Bethlehem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For forty days, every morning and evening, the Philistine champion strutted in front of the Israelite army.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One day Jesse said to David, “Take this basket of roasted grain and these ten loaves of bread, and carry them quickly to your brothers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And give these ten cuts of cheese to their captain. See how your brothers are getting along, and bring back a report on how they are doing.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David’s brothers were with Saul and the Israelite army at the valley of Elah, fighting against the Philistines.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David left the sheep with another shepherd and set out early the next morning with the gifts, as Jesse had directed him. He arrived at the camp just as the Israelite army was leaving for the battlefield with shouts and battle cries.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Soon the Israelite and Philistine forces stood facing each other, army against army.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David left his things with the keeper of supplies and hurried out to the ranks to greet his brothers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As he was talking with them, Goliath, the Philistine champion from Gath, came out from the Philistine ranks. Then David heard him shout his usual taunt to the army of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As soon as the Israelite army saw him, they began to run away in fright.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Have you seen the giant?” the men asked. “He comes out each day to defy Israel. The king has offered a huge reward to anyone who kills him. He will give that man one of his daughters for a wife, and the man’s entire family will be exempted from paying taxes!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David asked the soldiers standing nearby, “What will a man get for killing this Philistine and ending his defiance of Israel? Who is this pagan Philistine anyway, that he is allowed to defy the armies of the living God?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And these men gave David the same reply. They said, “Yes, that is the reward for killing him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator
