verses.text: But when David’s oldest brother, Eliab, heard David talking to the men, he was angry. “What are you doing around here anyway?” he demanded. “What about those few sheep you’re supposed to be taking care of? I know about your pride and deceit. You just want to see the battle!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “What have I done now?” David replied. “I was only asking a question!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He walked over to some others and asked them the same thing and received the same answer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David’s question was reported to King Saul, and the king sent for him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Don’t worry about this Philistine,” David told Saul. “I’ll go fight him!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Don’t be ridiculous!” Saul replied. “There’s no way you can fight this Philistine and possibly win! You’re only a boy, and he’s been a man of war since his youth.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But David persisted. “I have been taking care of my father’s sheep and goats,” he said. “When a lion or a bear comes to steal a lamb from the flock,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I go after it with a club and rescue the lamb from its mouth. If the animal turns on me, I catch it by the jaw and club it to death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have done this to both lions and bears, and I’ll do it to this pagan Philistine, too, for he has defied the armies of the living God!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Lord who rescued me from the claws of the lion and the bear will rescue me from this Philistine!”
Saul finally consented. “All right, go ahead,” he said. “And may the Lord be with you!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Saul gave David his own armor—a bronze helmet and a coat of mail.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
David put it on, strapped the sword over it, and took a step or two to see what it was like, for he had never worn such things before.
“I can’t go in these,” he protested to Saul. “I’m not used to them.” So David took them off again.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He picked up five smooth stones from a stream and put them into his shepherd’s bag. Then, armed only with his shepherd’s staff and sling, he started across the valley to fight the Philistine.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Goliath walked out toward David with his shield bearer ahead of him,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: sneering in contempt at this ruddy-faced boy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Am I a dog,” he roared at David, “that you come at me with a stick?” And he cursed David by the names of his gods.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Come over here, and I’ll give your flesh to the birds and wild animals!” Goliath yelled.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David replied to the Philistine, “You come to me with sword, spear, and javelin, but I come to you in the name of the Lord of Heaven’s Armies—the God of the armies of Israel, whom you have defied.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Today the Lord will conquer you, and I will kill you and cut off your head. And then I will give the dead bodies of your men to the birds and wild animals, and the whole world will know that there is a God in Israel!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And everyone assembled here will know that the Lord rescues his people, but not with sword and spear. This is the Lord’s battle, and he will give you to us!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As Goliath moved closer to attack, David quickly ran out to meet him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Reaching into his shepherd’s bag and taking out a stone, he hurled it with his sling and hit the Philistine in the forehead. The stone sank in, and Goliath stumbled and fell face down on the ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David triumphed over the Philistine with only a sling and a stone, for he had no sword.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then David ran over and pulled Goliath’s sword from its sheath. David used it to kill him and cut off his head.
When the Philistines saw that their champion was dead, they turned and ran.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the men of Israel and Judah gave a great shout of triumph and rushed after the Philistines, chasing them as far as Gath and the gates of Ekron. The bodies of the dead and wounded Philistines were strewn all along the road from Shaaraim, as far as Gath and Ekron.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Israelite army returned and plundered the deserted Philistine camp.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (David took the Philistine’s head to Jerusalem, but he stored the man’s armor in his own tent.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As Saul watched David go out to fight the Philistine, he asked Abner, the commander of his army, “Abner, whose son is this young man?”
“I really don’t know,” Abner declared.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Well, find out who he is!” the king told him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As soon as David returned from killing Goliath, Abner brought him to Saul with the Philistine’s head still in his hand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Tell me about your father, young man,” Saul said.
And David replied, “His name is Jesse, and we live in Bethlehem.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After David had finished talking with Saul, he met Jonathan, the king’s son. There was an immediate bond between them, for Jonathan loved David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From that day on Saul kept David with him and wouldn’t let him return home.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Jonathan made a solemn pact with David, because he loved him as he loved himself.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jonathan sealed the pact by taking off his robe and giving it to David, together with his tunic, sword, bow, and belt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whatever Saul asked David to do, David did it successfully. So Saul made him a commander over the men of war, an appointment that was welcomed by the people and Saul’s officers alike.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the victorious Israelite army was returning home after David had killed the Philistine, women from all the towns of Israel came out to meet King Saul. They sang and danced for joy with tambourines and cymbals.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This was their song: 
“Saul has killed his thousands,
    and David his ten thousands!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This made Saul very angry. “What’s this?” he said. “They credit David with ten thousands and me with only thousands. Next they’ll be making him their king!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So from that time on Saul kept a jealous eye on David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The very next day a tormenting spirit from God overwhelmed Saul, and he began to rave in his house like a madman. David was playing the harp, as he did each day. But Saul had a spear in his hand,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and he suddenly hurled it at David, intending to pin him to the wall. But David escaped him twice.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul was then afraid of David, for the Lord was with David and had turned away from Saul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Finally, Saul sent him away and appointed him commander over 1,000 men, and David faithfully led his troops into battle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David continued to succeed in everything he did, for the Lord was with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Saul recognized this, he became even more afraid of him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But all Israel and Judah loved David because he was so successful at leading his troops into battle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One day Saul said to David, “I am ready to give you my older daughter, Merab, as your wife. But first you must prove yourself to be a real warrior by fighting the Lord’s battles.” For Saul thought, “I’ll send him out against the Philistines and let them kill him rather than doing it myself.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Who am I, and what is my family in Israel that I should be the king’s son-in-law?” David exclaimed. “My father’s family is nothing!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So when the time came for Saul to give his daughter Merab in marriage to David, he gave her instead to Adriel, a man from Meholah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the meantime, Saul’s daughter Michal had fallen in love with David, and Saul was delighted when he heard about it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Here’s another chance to see him killed by the Philistines!” Saul said to himself. But to David he said, “Today you have a second chance to become my son-in-law!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Saul told his men to say to David, “The king really likes you, and so do we. Why don’t you accept the king’s offer and become his son-in-law?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Saul’s men said these things to David, he replied, “How can a poor man from a humble family afford the bride price for the daughter of a king?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Saul’s men reported this back to the king,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: he told them, “Tell David that all I want for the bride price is 100 Philistine foreskins! Vengeance on my enemies is all I really want.” But what Saul had in mind was that David would be killed in the fight.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David was delighted to accept the offer. Before the time limit expired,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: he and his men went out and killed 200 Philistines. Then David fulfilled the king’s requirement by presenting all their foreskins to him. So Saul gave his daughter Michal to David to be his wife.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Saul realized that the Lord was with David and how much his daughter Michal loved him,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul became even more afraid of him, and he remained David’s enemy for the rest of his life.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Every time the commanders of the Philistines attacked, David was more successful against them than all the rest of Saul’s officers. So David’s name became very famous.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul now urged his servants and his son Jonathan to assassinate David. But Jonathan, because of his strong affection for David,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: told him what his father was planning. “Tomorrow morning,” he warned him, “you must find a hiding place out in the fields.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I’ll ask my father to go out there with me, and I’ll talk to him about you. Then I’ll tell you everything I can find out.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The next morning Jonathan spoke with his father about David, saying many good things about him. “The king must not sin against his servant David,” Jonathan said. “He’s never done anything to harm you. He has always helped you in any way he could.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Have you forgotten about the time he risked his life to kill the Philistine giant and how the Lord brought a great victory to all Israel as a result? You were certainly happy about it then. Why should you murder an innocent man like David? There is no reason for it at all!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Saul listened to Jonathan and vowed, “As surely as the Lord lives, David will not be killed.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Afterward Jonathan called David and told him what had happened. Then he brought David to Saul, and David served in the court as before.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: War broke out again after that, and David led his troops against the Philistines. He attacked them with such fury that they all ran away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But one day when Saul was sitting at home, with spear in hand, the tormenting spirit from the Lord suddenly came upon him again. As David played his harp,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul hurled his spear at David. But David dodged out of the way, and leaving the spear stuck in the wall, he fled and escaped into the night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Saul sent troops to watch David’s house. They were told to kill David when he came out the next morning. But Michal, David’s wife, warned him, “If you don’t escape tonight, you will be dead by morning.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So she helped him climb out through a window, and he fled and escaped.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then she took an idol and put it in his bed, covered it with blankets, and put a cushion of goat’s hair at its head.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the troops came to arrest David, she told them he was sick and couldn’t get out of bed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Saul sent the troops back to get David. He ordered, “Bring him to me in his bed so I can kill him!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when they came to carry David out, they discovered that it was only an idol in the bed with a cushion of goat’s hair at its head.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Why have you betrayed me like this and let my enemy escape?” Saul demanded of Michal.
“I had to,” Michal replied. “He threatened to kill me if I didn’t help him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David escaped and went to Ramah to see Samuel, and he told him all that Saul had done to him. Then Samuel took David with him to live at Naioth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the report reached Saul that David was at Naioth in Ramah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: he sent troops to capture him. But when they arrived and saw Samuel leading a group of prophets who were prophesying, the Spirit of God came upon Saul’s men, and they also began to prophesy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Saul heard what had happened, he sent other troops, but they, too, prophesied! The same thing happened a third time.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Finally, Saul himself went to Ramah and arrived at the great well in Secu. “Where are Samuel and David?” he demanded.
“They are at Naioth in Ramah,” someone told him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But on the way to Naioth in Ramah the Spirit of God came even upon Saul, and he, too, began to prophesy all the way to Naioth!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He tore off his clothes and lay naked on the ground all day and all night, prophesying in the presence of Samuel. The people who were watching exclaimed, “What? Is even Saul a prophet?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David now fled from Naioth in Ramah and found Jonathan. “What have I done?” he exclaimed. “What is my crime? How have I offended your father that he is so determined to kill me?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “That’s not true!” Jonathan protested. “You’re not going to die. He always tells me everything he’s going to do, even the little things. I know my father wouldn’t hide something like this from me. It just isn’t so!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David took an oath before Jonathan and said, “Your father knows perfectly well about our friendship, so he has said to himself, ‘I won’t tell Jonathan—why should I hurt him?’ But I swear to you that I am only a step away from death! I swear it by the Lord and by your own soul!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Tell me what I can do to help you,” Jonathan exclaimed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David replied, “Tomorrow we celebrate the new moon festival. I’ve always eaten with the king on this occasion, but tomorrow I’ll hide in the field and stay there until the evening of the third day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If your father asks where I am, tell him I asked permission to go home to Bethlehem for an annual family sacrifice.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If he says, ‘Fine!’ you will know all is well. But if he is angry and loses his temper, you will know he is determined to kill me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Show me this loyalty as my sworn friend—for we made a solemn pact before the Lord—or kill me yourself if I have sinned against your father. But please don’t betray me to him!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Never!” Jonathan exclaimed. “You know that if I had the slightest notion my father was planning to kill you, I would tell you at once.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David asked, “How will I know whether or not your father is angry?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Come out to the field with me,” Jonathan replied. And they went out there together.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jonathan told David, “I promise by the Lord, the God of Israel, that by this time tomorrow, or the next day at the latest, I will talk to my father and let you know at once how he feels about you. If he speaks favorably about you, I will let you know.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if he is angry and wants you killed, may the Lord strike me and even kill me if I don’t warn you so you can escape and live. May the Lord be with you as he used to be with my father.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And may you treat me with the faithful love of the Lord as long as I live. But if I die,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: treat my family with this faithful love, even when the Lord destroys all your enemies from the face of the earth.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jonathan made a solemn pact with David, saying, “May the Lord destroy all your enemies!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Jonathan made David reaffirm his vow of friendship again, for Jonathan loved David as he loved himself.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jonathan said, “Tomorrow we celebrate the new moon festival. You will be missed when your place at the table is empty.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The day after tomorrow, toward evening, go to the place where you hid before, and wait there by the stone pile.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will come out and shoot three arrows to the side of the stone pile as though I were shooting at a target.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then I will send a boy to bring the arrows back. If you hear me tell him, ‘They’re on this side,’ then you will know, as surely as the Lord lives, that all is well, and there is no trouble.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if I tell him, ‘Go farther—the arrows are still ahead of you,’ then it will mean that you must leave immediately, for the Lord is sending you away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And may the Lord make us keep our promises to each other, for he has witnessed them.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David hid himself in the field, and when the new moon festival began, the king sat down to eat.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He sat at his usual place against the wall, with Jonathan sitting opposite him and Abner beside him. But David’s place was empty.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul didn’t say anything about it that day, for he said to himself, “Something must have made David ceremonially unclean.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when David’s place was empty again the next day, Saul asked Jonathan, “Why hasn’t the son of Jesse been here for the meal either yesterday or today?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jonathan replied, “David earnestly asked me if he could go to Bethlehem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said, ‘Please let me go, for we are having a family sacrifice. My brother demanded that I be there. So please let me get away to see my brothers.’ That’s why he isn’t here at the king’s table.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul boiled with rage at Jonathan. “You stupid son of a whore!” he swore at him. “Do you think I don’t know that you want him to be king in your place, shaming yourself and your mother?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As long as that son of Jesse is alive, you’ll never be king. Now go and get him so I can kill him!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “But why should he be put to death?” Jonathan asked his father. “What has he done?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Saul hurled his spear at Jonathan, intending to kill him. So at last Jonathan realized that his father was really determined to kill David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jonathan left the table in fierce anger and refused to eat on that second day of the festival, for he was crushed by his father’s shameful behavior toward David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The next morning, as agreed, Jonathan went out into the field and took a young boy with him to gather his arrows.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Start running,” he told the boy, “so you can find the arrows as I shoot them.” So the boy ran, and Jonathan shot an arrow beyond him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the boy had almost reached the arrow, Jonathan shouted, “The arrow is still ahead of you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hurry, hurry, don’t wait.” So the boy quickly gathered up the arrows and ran back to his master.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He, of course, suspected nothing; only Jonathan and David understood the signal.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jonathan gave his bow and arrows to the boy and told him to take them back to town.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As soon as the boy was gone, David came out from where he had been hiding near the stone pile. Then David bowed three times to Jonathan with his face to the ground. Both of them were in tears as they embraced each other and said good-bye, especially David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At last Jonathan said to David, “Go in peace, for we have sworn loyalty to each other in the Lord’s name. The Lord is the witness of a bond between us and our children forever.” Then David left, and Jonathan returned to the town.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David went to the town of Nob to see Ahimelech the priest. Ahimelech trembled when he saw him. “Why are you alone?” he asked. “Why is no one with you?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “The king has sent me on a private matter,” David said. “He told me not to tell anyone why I am here. I have told my men where to meet me later.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, what is there to eat? Give me five loaves of bread or anything else you have.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “We don’t have any regular bread,” the priest replied. “But there is the holy bread, which you can have if your young men have not slept with any women recently.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Don’t worry,” David replied. “I never allow my men to be with women when we are on a campaign. And since they stay clean even on ordinary trips, how much more on this one!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Since there was no other food available, the priest gave him the holy bread—the Bread of the Presence that was placed before the Lord in the Tabernacle. It had just been replaced that day with fresh bread.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Doeg the Edomite, Saul’s chief herdsman, was there that day, having been detained before the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David asked Ahimelech, “Do you have a spear or sword? The king’s business was so urgent that I didn’t even have time to grab a weapon!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“I only have the sword of Goliath the Philistine, whom you killed in the valley of Elah,” the priest replied. “It is wrapped in a cloth behind the ephod. Take that if you want it, for there is nothing else here.”
“There is nothing like it!” David replied. “Give it to me!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David escaped from Saul and went to King Achish of Gath.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But the officers of Achish were unhappy about his being there. “Isn’t this David, the king of the land?” they asked. “Isn’t he the one the people honor with dances, singing,
‘Saul has killed his thousands,
    and David his ten thousands’?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David heard these comments and was very afraid of what King Achish of Gath might do to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he pretended to be insane, scratching on doors and drooling down his beard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Finally, King Achish said to his men, “Must you bring me a madman?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We already have enough of them around here! Why should I let someone like this be my guest?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David left Gath and escaped to the cave of Adullam. Soon his brothers and all his other relatives joined him there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then others began coming—men who were in trouble or in debt or who were just discontented—until David was the captain of about 400 men.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Later David went to Mizpeh in Moab, where he asked the king, “Please allow my father and mother to live here with you until I know what God is going to do for me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David’s parents stayed in Moab with the king during the entire time David was living in his stronghold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One day the prophet Gad told David, “Leave the stronghold and return to the land of Judah.” So David went to the forest of Hereth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The news of his arrival in Judah soon reached Saul. At the time, the king was sitting beneath the tamarisk tree on the hill at Gibeah, holding his spear and surrounded by his officers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Listen here, you men of Benjamin!” Saul shouted to his officers when he heard the news. “Has that son of Jesse promised every one of you fields and vineyards? Has he promised to make you all generals and captains in his army?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Is that why you have conspired against me? For not one of you told me when my own son made a solemn pact with the son of Jesse. You’re not even sorry for me. Think of it! My own son—encouraging him to kill me, as he is trying to do this very day!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Doeg the Edomite, who was standing there with Saul’s men, spoke up. “When I was at Nob,” he said, “I saw the son of Jesse talking to the priest, Ahimelech son of Ahitub.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahimelech consulted the Lord for him. Then he gave him food and the sword of Goliath the Philistine.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Saul immediately sent for Ahimelech and all his family, who served as priests at Nob.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When they arrived, Saul shouted at him, “Listen to me, you son of Ahitub!”
“What is it, my king?” Ahimelech asked.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Why have you and the son of Jesse conspired against me?” Saul demanded. “Why did you give him food and a sword? Why have you consulted God for him? Why have you encouraged him to kill me, as he is trying to do this very day?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “But sir,” Ahimelech replied, “is anyone among all your servants as faithful as David, your son-in-law? Why, he is the captain of your bodyguard and a highly honored member of your household!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This was certainly not the first time I had consulted God for him! May the king not accuse me and my family in this matter, for I knew nothing at all of any plot against you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “You will surely die, Ahimelech, along with your entire family!” the king shouted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And he ordered his bodyguards, “Kill these priests of the Lord, for they are allies and conspirators with David! They knew he was running away from me, but they didn’t tell me!” But Saul’s men refused to kill the Lord’s priests.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king said to Doeg, “You do it.” So Doeg the Edomite turned on them and killed them that day, eighty-five priests in all, still wearing their priestly garments.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he went to Nob, the town of the priests, and killed the priests’ families—men and women, children and babies—and all the cattle, donkeys, sheep, and goats.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Only Abiathar, one of the sons of Ahimelech, escaped and fled to David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he told David that Saul had killed the priests of the Lord,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David exclaimed, “I knew it! When I saw Doeg the Edomite there that day, I knew he was sure to tell Saul. Now I have caused the death of all your father’s family.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Stay here with me, and don’t be afraid. I will protect you with my own life, for the same person wants to kill us both.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One day news came to David that the Philistines were at Keilah stealing grain from the threshing floors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
David asked the Lord, “Should I go and attack them?”
“Yes, go and save Keilah,” the Lord told him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But David’s men said, “We’re afraid even here in Judah. We certainly don’t want to go to Keilah to fight the whole Philistine army!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David asked the Lord again, and again the Lord replied, “Go down to Keilah, for I will help you conquer the Philistines.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David and his men went to Keilah. They slaughtered the Philistines and took all their livestock and rescued the people of Keilah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now when Abiathar son of Ahimelech fled to David at Keilah, he brought the ephod with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul soon learned that David was at Keilah. “Good!” he exclaimed. “We’ve got him now! God has handed him over to me, for he has trapped himself in a walled town!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Saul mobilized his entire army to march to Keilah and besiege David and his men.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But David learned of Saul’s plan and told Abiathar the priest to bring the ephod and ask the Lord what he should do.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David prayed, “O Lord, God of Israel, I have heard that Saul is planning to come and destroy Keilah because I am here.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Will the leaders of Keilah betray me to him? And will Saul actually come as I have heard? O Lord, God of Israel, please tell me.”
And the Lord said, “He will come.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Again David asked, “Will the leaders of Keilah betray me and my men to Saul?”
And the Lord replied, “Yes, they will betray you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David and his men—about 600 of them now—left Keilah and began roaming the countryside. Word soon reached Saul that David had escaped, so he didn’t go to Keilah after all.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David now stayed in the strongholds of the wilderness and in the hill country of Ziph. Saul hunted him day after day, but God didn’t let Saul find him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One day near Horesh, David received the news that Saul was on the way to Ziph to search for him and kill him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jonathan went to find David and encouraged him to stay strong in his faith in God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Don’t be afraid,” Jonathan reassured him. “My father will never find you! You are going to be the king of Israel, and I will be next to you, as my father, Saul, is well aware.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the two of them renewed their solemn pact before the Lord. Then Jonathan returned home, while David stayed at Horesh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But now the men of Ziph went to Saul in Gibeah and betrayed David to him. “We know where David is hiding,” they said. “He is in the strongholds of Horesh on the hill of Hakilah, which is in the southern part of Jeshimon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Come down whenever you’re ready, O king, and we will catch him and hand him over to you!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “The Lord bless you,” Saul said. “At last someone is concerned about me!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Go and check again to be sure of where he is staying and who has seen him there, for I know that he is very crafty.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Discover his hiding places, and come back when you are sure. Then I’ll go with you. And if he is in the area at all, I’ll track him down, even if I have to search every hiding place in Judah!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So the men of Ziph returned home ahead of Saul.
Meanwhile, David and his men had moved into the wilderness of Maon in the Arabah Valley south of Jeshimon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David heard that Saul and his men were searching for him, he went even farther into the wilderness to the great rock, and he remained there in the wilderness of Maon. But Saul kept after him in the wilderness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul and David were now on opposite sides of a mountain. Just as Saul and his men began to close in on David and his men,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: an urgent message reached Saul that the Philistines were raiding Israel again.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Saul quit chasing David and returned to fight the Philistines. Ever since that time, the place where David was camped has been called the Rock of Escape.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David then went to live in the strongholds of En-gedi.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After Saul returned from fighting the Philistines, he was told that David had gone into the wilderness of En-gedi.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Saul chose 3,000 elite troops from all Israel and went to search for David and his men near the rocks of the wild goats.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At the place where the road passes some sheepfolds, Saul went into a cave to relieve himself. But as it happened, David and his men were hiding farther back in that very cave!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Now’s your opportunity!” David’s men whispered to him. “Today the Lord is telling you, ‘I will certainly put your enemy into your power, to do with as you wish.’” So David crept forward and cut off a piece of the hem of Saul’s robe.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But then David’s conscience began bothering him because he had cut Saul’s robe.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said to his men, “The Lord forbid that I should do this to my lord the king. I shouldn’t attack the Lord’s anointed one, for the Lord himself has chosen him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So David restrained his men and did not let them kill Saul.
After Saul had left the cave and gone on his way,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David came out and shouted after him, “My lord the king!” And when Saul looked around, David bowed low before him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he shouted to Saul, “Why do you listen to the people who say I am trying to harm you?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This very day you can see with your own eyes it isn’t true. For the Lord placed you at my mercy back there in the cave. Some of my men told me to kill you, but I spared you. For I said, ‘I will never harm the king—he is the Lord’s anointed one.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Look, my father, at what I have in my hand. It is a piece of the hem of your robe! I cut it off, but I didn’t kill you. This proves that I am not trying to harm you and that I have not sinned against you, even though you have been hunting for me to kill me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “May the Lord judge between us. Perhaps the Lord will punish you for what you are trying to do to me, but I will never harm you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As that old proverb says, ‘From evil people come evil deeds.’ So you can be sure I will never harm you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Who is the king of Israel trying to catch anyway? Should he spend his time chasing one who is as worthless as a dead dog or a single flea?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: May the Lord therefore judge which of us is right and punish the guilty one. He is my advocate, and he will rescue me from your power!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David had finished speaking, Saul called back, “Is that really you, my son David?” Then he began to cry.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And he said to David, “You are a better man than I am, for you have repaid me good for evil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yes, you have been amazingly kind to me today, for when the Lord put me in a place where you could have killed me, you didn’t do it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Who else would let his enemy get away when he had him in his power? May the Lord reward you well for the kindness you have shown me today.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And now I realize that you are surely going to be king, and that the kingdom of Israel will flourish under your rule.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now swear to me by the Lord that when that happens you will not kill my family and destroy my line of descendants!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David promised this to Saul with an oath. Then Saul went home, but David and his men went back to their stronghold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Now Samuel died, and all Israel gathered for his funeral. They buried him at his house in Ramah.
Then David moved down to the wilderness of Maon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was a wealthy man from Maon who owned property near the town of Carmel. He had 3,000 sheep and 1,000 goats, and it was sheep-shearing time.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This man’s name was Nabal, and his wife, Abigail, was a sensible and beautiful woman. But Nabal, a descendant of Caleb, was crude and mean in all his dealings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David heard that Nabal was shearing his sheep,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: he sent ten of his young men to Carmel with this message for Nabal:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Peace and prosperity to you, your family, and everything you own!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I am told that it is sheep-shearing time. While your shepherds stayed among us near Carmel, we never harmed them, and nothing was ever stolen from them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ask your own men, and they will tell you this is true. So would you be kind to us, since we have come at a time of celebration? Please share any provisions you might have on hand with us and with your friend David.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David’s young men gave this message to Nabal in David’s name, and they waited for a reply.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Who is this fellow David?” Nabal sneered to the young men. “Who does this son of Jesse think he is? There are lots of servants these days who run away from their masters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Should I take my bread and my water and my meat that I’ve slaughtered for my shearers and give it to a band of outlaws who come from who knows where?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David’s young men returned and told him what Nabal had said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Get your swords!” was David’s reply as he strapped on his own. Then 400 men started off with David, and 200 remained behind to guard their equipment.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Meanwhile, one of Nabal’s servants went to Abigail and told her, “David sent messengers from the wilderness to greet our master, but he screamed insults at them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These men have been very good to us, and we never suffered any harm from them. Nothing was stolen from us the whole time they were with us.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In fact, day and night they were like a wall of protection to us and the sheep.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You need to know this and figure out what to do, for there is going to be trouble for our master and his whole family. He’s so ill-tempered that no one can even talk to him!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abigail wasted no time. She quickly gathered 200 loaves of bread, two wineskins full of wine, five sheep that had been slaughtered, nearly a bushel of roasted grain, 100 clusters of raisins, and 200 fig cakes. She packed them on donkeys
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and said to her servants, “Go on ahead. I will follow you shortly.” But she didn’t tell her husband Nabal what she was doing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As she was riding her donkey into a mountain ravine, she saw David and his men coming toward her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David had just been saying, “A lot of good it did to help this fellow. We protected his flocks in the wilderness, and nothing he owned was lost or stolen. But he has repaid me evil for good.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: May God strike me and kill me if even one man of his household is still alive tomorrow morning!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Abigail saw David, she quickly got off her donkey and bowed low before him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She fell at his feet and said, “I accept all blame in this matter, my lord. Please listen to what I have to say.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I know Nabal is a wicked and ill-tempered man; please don’t pay any attention to him. He is a fool, just as his name suggests. But I never even saw the young men you sent.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Now, my lord, as surely as the Lord lives and you yourself live, since the Lord has kept you from murdering and taking vengeance into your own hands, let all your enemies and those who try to harm you be as cursed as Nabal is.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And here is a present that I, your servant, have brought to you and your young men.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Please forgive me if I have offended you in any way. The Lord will surely reward you with a lasting dynasty, for you are fighting the Lord’s battles. And you have not done wrong throughout your entire life.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Even when you are chased by those who seek to kill you, your life is safe in the care of the Lord your God, secure in his treasure pouch! But the lives of your enemies will disappear like stones shot from a sling!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Lord has done all he promised and has made you leader of Israel,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: don’t let this be a blemish on your record. Then your conscience won’t have to bear the staggering burden of needless bloodshed and vengeance. And when the Lord has done these great things for you, please remember me, your servant!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David replied to Abigail, “Praise the Lord, the God of Israel, who has sent you to meet me today!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Thank God for your good sense! Bless you for keeping me from murder and from carrying out vengeance with my own hands.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For I swear by the Lord, the God of Israel, who has kept me from hurting you, that if you had not hurried out to meet me, not one of Nabal’s men would still be alive tomorrow morning.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David accepted her present and told her, “Return home in peace. I have heard what you said. We will not kill your husband.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Abigail arrived home, she found that Nabal was throwing a big party and was celebrating like a king. He was very drunk, so she didn’t tell him anything about her meeting with David until dawn the next day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the morning when Nabal was sober, his wife told him what had happened. As a result he had a stroke, and he lay paralyzed on his bed like a stone.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: About ten days later, the Lord struck him, and he died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David heard that Nabal was dead, he said, “Praise the Lord, who has avenged the insult I received from Nabal and has kept me from doing it myself. Nabal has received the punishment for his sin.” Then David sent messengers to Abigail to ask her to become his wife.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the messengers arrived at Carmel, they told Abigail, “David has sent us to take you back to marry him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She bowed low to the ground and responded, “I, your servant, would be happy to marry David. I would even be willing to become a slave, washing the feet of his servants!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Quickly getting ready, she took along five of her servant girls as attendants, mounted her donkey, and went with David’s messengers. And so she became his wife.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David also married Ahinoam from Jezreel, making both of them his wives.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul, meanwhile, had given his daughter Michal, David’s wife, to a man from Gallim named Palti son of Laish.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now some men from Ziph came to Saul at Gibeah to tell him, “David is hiding on the hill of Hakilah, which overlooks Jeshimon.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Saul took 3,000 of Israel’s elite troops and went to hunt him down in the wilderness of Ziph.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul camped along the road beside the hill of Hakilah, near Jeshimon, where David was hiding. When David learned that Saul had come after him into the wilderness,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: he sent out spies to verify the report of Saul’s arrival.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David slipped over to Saul’s camp one night to look around. Saul and Abner son of Ner, the commander of his army, were sleeping inside a ring formed by the slumbering warriors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Who will volunteer to go in there with me?” David asked Ahimelech the Hittite and Abishai son of Zeruiah, Joab’s brother.
“I’ll go with you,” Abishai replied.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David and Abishai went right into Saul’s camp and found him asleep, with his spear stuck in the ground beside his head. Abner and the soldiers were lying asleep around him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “God has surely handed your enemy over to you this time!” Abishai whispered to David. “Let me pin him to the ground with one thrust of the spear; I won’t need to strike twice!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “No!” David said. “Don’t kill him. For who can remain innocent after attacking the Lord’s anointed one?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Surely the Lord will strike Saul down someday, or he will die of old age or in battle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord forbid that I should kill the one he has anointed! But take his spear and that jug of water beside his head, and then let’s get out of here!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David took the spear and jug of water that were near Saul’s head. Then he and Abishai got away without anyone seeing them or even waking up, because the Lord had put Saul’s men into a deep sleep.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David climbed the hill opposite the camp until he was at a safe distance.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then he shouted down to the soldiers and to Abner son of Ner, “Wake up, Abner!”
“Who is it?” Abner demanded.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Well, Abner, you’re a great man, aren’t you?” David taunted. “Where in all Israel is there anyone as mighty? So why haven’t you guarded your master the king when someone came to kill him?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This isn’t good at all! I swear by the Lord that you and your men deserve to die, because you failed to protect your master, the Lord’s anointed! Look around! Where are the king’s spear and the jug of water that were beside his head?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Saul recognized David’s voice and called out, “Is that you, my son David?”
And David replied, “Yes, my lord the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Why are you chasing me? What have I done? What is my crime?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But now let my lord the king listen to his servant. If the Lord has stirred you up against me, then let him accept my offering. But if this is simply a human scheme, then may those involved be cursed by the Lord. For they have driven me from my home, so I can no longer live among the Lord’s people, and they have said, ‘Go, worship pagan gods.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Must I die on foreign soil, far from the presence of the Lord? Why has the king of Israel come out to search for a single flea? Why does he hunt me down like a partridge on the mountains?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Saul confessed, “I have sinned. Come back home, my son, and I will no longer try to harm you, for you valued my life today. I have been a fool and very, very wrong.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Here is your spear, O king,” David replied. “Let one of your young men come over and get it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord gives his own reward for doing good and for being loyal, and I refused to kill you even when the Lord placed you in my power, for you are the Lord’s anointed one.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now may the Lord value my life, even as I have valued yours today. May he rescue me from all my troubles.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Saul said to David, “Blessings on you, my son David. You will do many heroic deeds, and you will surely succeed.” Then David went away, and Saul returned home.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But David kept thinking to himself, “Someday Saul is going to get me. The best thing I can do is escape to the Philistines. Then Saul will stop hunting for me in Israelite territory, and I will finally be safe.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David took his 600 men and went over and joined Achish son of Maoch, the king of Gath.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David and his men and their families settled there with Achish at Gath. David brought his two wives along with him—Ahinoam from Jezreel and Abigail, Nabal’s widow from Carmel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Word soon reached Saul that David had fled to Gath, so he stopped hunting for him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One day David said to Achish, “If it is all right with you, we would rather live in one of the country towns instead of here in the royal city.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Achish gave him the town of Ziklag (which still belongs to the kings of Judah to this day),
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and they lived there among the Philistines for a year and four months.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David and his men spent their time raiding the Geshurites, the Girzites, and the Amalekites—people who had lived near Shur, toward the land of Egypt, since ancient times.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David did not leave one person alive in the villages he attacked. He took the sheep, goats, cattle, donkeys, camels, and clothing before returning home to see King Achish.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Where did you make your raid today?” Achish would ask.
And David would reply, “Against the south of Judah, the Jerahmeelites, and the Kenites.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: No one was left alive to come to Gath and tell where he had really been. This happened again and again while he was living among the Philistines.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Achish believed David and thought to himself, “By now the people of Israel must hate him bitterly. Now he will have to stay here and serve me forever!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: About that time the Philistines mustered their armies for another war with Israel. King Achish told David, “You and your men will be expected to join me in battle.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Very well!” David agreed. “Now you will see for yourself what we can do.”
Then Achish told David, “I will make you my personal bodyguard for life.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Meanwhile, Samuel had died, and all Israel had mourned for him. He was buried in Ramah, his hometown. And Saul had banned from the land of Israel all mediums and those who consult the spirits of the dead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Philistines set up their camp at Shunem, and Saul gathered all the army of Israel and camped at Gilboa.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Saul saw the vast Philistine army, he became frantic with fear.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He asked the Lord what he should do, but the Lord refused to answer him, either by dreams or by sacred lots or by the prophets.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Saul then said to his advisers, “Find a woman who is a medium, so I can go and ask her what to do.”
His advisers replied, “There is a medium at Endor.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So Saul disguised himself by wearing ordinary clothing instead of his royal robes. Then he went to the woman’s home at night, accompanied by two of his men.
“I have to talk to a man who has died,” he said. “Will you call up his spirit for me?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Are you trying to get me killed?” the woman demanded. “You know that Saul has outlawed all the mediums and all who consult the spirits of the dead. Why are you setting a trap for me?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Saul took an oath in the name of the Lord and promised, “As surely as the Lord lives, nothing bad will happen to you for doing this.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Finally, the woman said, “Well, whose spirit do you want me to call up?”
“Call up Samuel,” Saul replied.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the woman saw Samuel, she screamed, “You’ve deceived me! You are Saul!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Don’t be afraid!” the king told her. “What do you see?”
“I see a god coming up out of the earth,” she said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“What does he look like?” Saul asked.
“He is an old man wrapped in a robe,” she replied. Saul realized it was Samuel, and he fell to the ground before him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Why have you disturbed me by calling me back?” Samuel asked Saul.
“Because I am in deep trouble,” Saul replied. “The Philistines are at war with me, and God has left me and won’t reply by prophets or dreams. So I have called for you to tell me what to do.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Samuel replied, “Why ask me, since the Lord has left you and has become your enemy?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord has done just as he said he would. He has torn the kingdom from you and given it to your rival, David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord has done this to you today because you refused to carry out his fierce anger against the Amalekites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: What’s more, the Lord will hand you and the army of Israel over to the Philistines tomorrow, and you and your sons will be here with me. The Lord will bring down the entire army of Israel in defeat.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul fell full length on the ground, paralyzed with fright because of Samuel’s words. He was also faint with hunger, for he had eaten nothing all day and all night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the woman saw how distraught he was, she said, “Sir, I obeyed your command at the risk of my life.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now do what I say, and let me give you a little something to eat so you can regain your strength for the trip back.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Saul refused to eat anything. Then his advisers joined the woman in urging him to eat, so he finally yielded and got up from the ground and sat on the couch.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The woman had been fattening a calf, so she hurried out and killed it. She took some flour, kneaded it into dough and baked unleavened bread.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She brought the meal to Saul and his advisers, and they ate it. Then they went out into the night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The entire Philistine army now mobilized at Aphek, and the Israelites camped at the spring in Jezreel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As the Philistine rulers were leading out their troops in groups of hundreds and thousands, David and his men marched at the rear with King Achish.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But the Philistine commanders demanded, “What are these Hebrews doing here?”
And Achish told them, “This is David, the servant of King Saul of Israel. He’s been with me for years, and I’ve never found a single fault in him from the day he arrived until today.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the Philistine commanders were angry. “Send him back to the town you’ve given him!” they demanded. “He can’t go into the battle with us. What if he turns against us in battle and becomes our adversary? Is there any better way for him to reconcile himself with his master than by handing our heads over to him?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Isn’t this the same David about whom the women of Israel sing in their dances, 
‘Saul has killed his thousands,
    and David his ten thousands’?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Achish finally summoned David and said to him, “I swear by the Lord that you have been a trustworthy ally. I think you should go with me into battle, for I’ve never found a single flaw in you from the day you arrived until today. But the other Philistine rulers won’t hear of it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Please don’t upset them, but go back quietly.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “What have I done to deserve this treatment?” David demanded. “What have you ever found in your servant, that I can’t go and fight the enemies of my lord the king?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Achish insisted, “As far as I’m concerned, you’re as perfect as an angel of God. But the Philistine commanders are afraid to have you with them in the battle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now get up early in the morning, and leave with your men as soon as it gets light.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David and his men headed back into the land of the Philistines, while the Philistine army went on to Jezreel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Three days later, when David and his men arrived home at their town of Ziklag, they found that the Amalekites had made a raid into the Negev and Ziklag; they had crushed Ziklag and burned it to the ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They had carried off the women and children and everyone else but without killing anyone.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David and his men saw the ruins and realized what had happened to their families,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: they wept until they could weep no more.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David’s two wives, Ahinoam from Jezreel and Abigail, the widow of Nabal from Carmel, were among those captured.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David was now in great danger because all his men were very bitter about losing their sons and daughters, and they began to talk of stoning him. But David found strength in the Lord his God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he said to Abiathar the priest, “Bring me the ephod!” So Abiathar brought it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then David asked the Lord, “Should I chase after this band of raiders? Will I catch them?”
And the Lord told him, “Yes, go after them. You will surely recover everything that was taken from you!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David and his 600 men set out, and they came to the brook Besor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But 200 of the men were too exhausted to cross the brook, so David continued the pursuit with 400 men.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Along the way they found an Egyptian man in a field and brought him to David. They gave him some bread to eat and water to drink.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They also gave him part of a fig cake and two clusters of raisins, for he hadn’t had anything to eat or drink for three days and nights. Before long his strength returned.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“To whom do you belong, and where do you come from?” David asked him.
“I am an Egyptian—the slave of an Amalekite,” he replied. “My master abandoned me three days ago because I was sick.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We were on our way back from raiding the Kerethites in the Negev, the territory of Judah, and the land of Caleb, and we had just burned Ziklag.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Will you lead me to this band of raiders?” David asked.
The young man replied, “If you take an oath in God’s name that you will not kill me or give me back to my master, then I will guide you to them.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he led David to them, and they found the Amalekites spread out across the fields, eating and drinking and dancing with joy because of the vast amount of plunder they had taken from the Philistines and the land of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David and his men rushed in among them and slaughtered them throughout that night and the entire next day until evening. None of the Amalekites escaped except 400 young men who fled on camels.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David got back everything the Amalekites had taken, and he rescued his two wives.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nothing was missing: small or great, son or daughter, nor anything else that had been taken. David brought everything back.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also recovered all the flocks and herds, and his men drove them ahead of the other livestock. “This plunder belongs to David!” they said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David returned to the brook Besor and met up with the 200 men who had been left behind because they were too exhausted to go with him. They went out to meet David and his men, and David greeted them joyfully.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But some evil troublemakers among David’s men said, “They didn’t go with us, so they can’t have any of the plunder we recovered. Give them their wives and children, and tell them to be gone.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But David said, “No, my brothers! Don’t be selfish with what the Lord has given us. He has kept us safe and helped us defeat the band of raiders that attacked us.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Who will listen when you talk like this? We share and share alike—those who go to battle and those who guard the equipment.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From then on David made this a decree and regulation for Israel, and it is still followed today.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he arrived at Ziklag, David sent part of the plunder to the elders of Judah, who were his friends. “Here is a present for you, taken from the Lord’s enemies,” he said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The gifts were sent to the people of the following towns David had visited: Bethel, Ramoth-negev, Jattir,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Aroer, Siphmoth, Eshtemoa,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Racal, the towns of the Jerahmeelites, the towns of the Kenites,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hormah, Bor-ashan, Athach,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hebron, and all the other places David and his men had visited.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the Philistines attacked Israel, and the men of Israel fled before them. Many were slaughtered on the slopes of Mount Gilboa.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Philistines closed in on Saul and his sons, and they killed three of his sons—Jonathan, Abinadab, and Malkishua.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The fighting grew very fierce around Saul, and the Philistine archers caught up with him and wounded him severely.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Saul groaned to his armor bearer, “Take your sword and kill me before these pagan Philistines come to run me through and taunt and torture me.”
But his armor bearer was afraid and would not do it. So Saul took his own sword and fell on it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When his armor bearer realized that Saul was dead, he fell on his own sword and died beside the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Saul, his three sons, his armor bearer, and his troops all died together that same day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Israelites on the other side of the Jezreel Valley and beyond the Jordan saw that the Israelite army had fled and that Saul and his sons were dead, they abandoned their towns and fled. So the Philistines moved in and occupied their towns.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The next day, when the Philistines went out to strip the dead, they found the bodies of Saul and his three sons on Mount Gilboa.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they cut off Saul’s head and stripped off his armor. Then they proclaimed the good news of Saul’s death in their pagan temple and to the people throughout the land of Philistia.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They placed his armor in the temple of the Ashtoreths, and they fastened his body to the wall of the city of Beth-shan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when the people of Jabesh-gilead heard what the Philistines had done to Saul,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: all their mighty warriors traveled through the night to Beth-shan and took the bodies of Saul and his sons down from the wall. They brought them to Jabesh, where they burned the bodies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they took their bones and buried them beneath the tamarisk tree at Jabesh, and they fasted for seven days.
verses.speaker: Narrator
